newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada minister hopes to see free lumber trade.
newsitem.headline: Canada minister hopes to see free lumber trade.

text.p: Canada's trade minister said on Thursday he hopes softwood lumber trade between Canada and the United States will revert to a free market system after the current quota system ends.
"I think (the agreement) is working fairly well, considering," Trade Minister Art Eggleton told a parliamentary committee. "But I'd like to see us go to a free flow once this five years is up."

April 1, 1997 marked the first anniversary of a five-year agreement limiting fee-free softwood lumber exports to the United States to 14.7 billion board feet of lumber per year. Companies exceeding their quotas must pay fees ranging from US$50 to US$100 per 1,000 board feet.
The quota system put an end to constant cross-border squabbling over Canada's lumber exports and gave the industry the stability it was asking for, Eggleton said.
"I prefer to have an open, free market in lumber. The deal we got was the best in a bad situation," he said.
Prices of softwood lumber have shot up since the quota system was introduced, making the fees for extra exports less painful, noted Eggleton.
Canada exported about 15.78 billion board feet of lumber to the United States in the first year of the quota system.
